qas.question: What popular musical casted a teacher-dealer?
What did these teacher-dealers often conduct?
How many people were usually in these teacher-dealer orchestras?
Who played the mandolin in Vaudeville?
Who was the famous African American musican and director?
What popular musical casted a student-dealer?
What did these student-dealers often conduct?
How many people were usually in these student-dealer orchestras?
Who refused to play the mandolin in Vaudeville?
Who was the famous North American musican and director?

context: Instruments were marketed by teacher-dealers, much as the title character in the popular musical <a0_0><b5_0>The Music Man<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Often, these teacher-dealers conducted <a1_0><b6_0>mandolin orchestras<b6_0/><a1_0/>: groups of <a2_0><b7_0>4-50<b7_0/> musicians<a2_0/> who played various mandolin family instruments. However, alongside the teacher-dealers were serious musicians, working to create a spot for the instrument in classical music, ragtime and jazz. Like the teacher-dealers, they traveled the U.S., recording records, giving performances and teaching individuals and mandolin orchestras. <a3_0><b8_0>Samuel Siegel<b8_0/><a3_0/> played mandolin in Vaudeville and became one of America's preeminent mandolinists. Seth Weeks was an African American who not only taught and performed in the United States, but also in Europe, where he recorded records. Another pioneering African American musician and director who made his start with a mandolin orchestra was <a4_0>composer <b9_0>James Reese Europe<b9_0/>.<a4_0/> W. Eugene Page toured the country with a group, and was well known for his mandolin and mandola performances. Other names include Valentine Abt, Samuel Adelstein, William Place, Jr., and Aubrey Stauffer.
